Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Oxide surfaces are increasingly important for both scientific and technological areas ranging from more energy-efficient catalysts to new types of electronic devices. Currently not enough is understood about the structure of oxide surfaces to predict what type of materials will be best for future needs. This project is developing tools to understand both the structure of oxide surfaces, as well as how they react with gaseous species. The tools that are developed can then be used by others who are designing interfaces involving these systems, or are exploring their use in new fuel cells, more efficient water-splitting catalysts or substrates upon which to grow new types of oxide-based electronic devices.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The strategy employed combines extended density-functional theory (DFT) methods including exact-exchange hybrids and the bond-valence chemical concepts in a combined experimental-theoretical approach exploiting some unique ultra-high vacuum (UHV) electron microscopy facilities. The main experimental tools are transmission electron microscopy imaging and diffraction to solve the surface structures. In addition to using DFT methods for the surface structures found, the research team is expanding the database of published atomic positions and tests of the bond-valence approach by performing calculations on other oxide surfaces where full details of the atomic positions are not publically available. One additional component is developing algorithms for DFT and related optimization codes, particularly quasi-Newton methods. The software for DFT has already been incorporated into one large package used by more than 1800 groups around the world (www.numis.northwestern.edu). In terms of education, the research helps support both local outreach to high-school students as part of existing programs, as well as more international efforts involving the general public license (GNU) software electron direct methods (edm).

POR.DRECONTENT:
How the atoms are arranged at the surfaces of compounds of oxygen and metals plays a critical role in a large number of processes of technological importance, ranging from the production of chemicals in industry using catalysts to how bridges corrode to form rust and how patients tolerate hip or other implants made of metals. Despite this wide importance, we do not understand well how the atoms are arranged and often very simplified models are made which can lead to misleading predictions. The Intellectual Merit of the work was to understand and predict what are the low energy structures of oxide surfaces, as well as a smaller continuation of previous work developing algorithms for theoretical calculations in a code that is used by more than two thousand groups around the world. We improved considerable upon our understanding of the complex surface structures of strontium titanate, finding a number of unusual arrangements of the atoms and also developing methods to predict what the structures will be with other oxides. Some of this work has already started to be used to design better materials such as catalysts for industrial applications. Among the Broader Impacts of the work was involvement in a number of international schools to help scientists better understand how to advanced methods of understanding surfaces, as well as assisting scientists from around the world to perform better theoretical calculations. The algorithms developed within the project allows these scientists to perform their calculations two to three times faster.
